newsitem.title: UK: Disney spreads wings, launches Kiwi bond.
newsitem.headline: Disney spreads wings, launches Kiwi bond.

text.p: Walt Disney Co further diversified its funding on Tuesday by tapping the New Zealand dollar sector for the first time, lead manager Hambros Bank said.
"The decision to tap the (New Zealand dollar) market originated from Walt Disney's desire to diversify their funding routes to retail sectors," Hambros Bank said in a statement.
Disney tapped the Italian lire and Swiss franc sectors earlier this year with success.
"Disney is a fantastic retail name. Its a coup for us to bring this type of name to market," a syndicate manager at Hambros said.
The bond sold "exceptionally well" to German, Swiss and Benelux retail investors, he added.

The NZ$100 million three-year offering pays a 7.25 percent coupon. The Hambros syndicate official said at the 99.90 reoffer price it offered a spread of 15 basis points over New Zealand government paper.
But officials in the syndicate criticised the low coupon. They said coupons below 8.00 percent were too tight.
"Walt Disney pushes the retail sector to the limit," a syndicate manager in Amsterdam said.
Another syndicate official in Frankfurt said: "It (the bond) should live on its name although it is quite expensive."
The issue follows AAA-rated deals in October from Deutsche Bank -- with a 7.75 percent two-year issue -- and Kreditanstalt Fuer Weideraufbau, with a 7.50 percent five-year bond.
The New Zealand dollar sector, said to be a candidate for retail sector of the year after coming to life in the Spring, has seen a number of top-notch borrowers.
Walt Disney was downgraded in February after its acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. It is now rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's Corp.
In August, Disney launched a 125 million Swiss franc bond due December 2000 which paid a 4.0 percent coupon. In May, it issued a 300 billion lire four-year bond which paid an 8.625 percent coupon.
